this means all the sensors will be recreated regardless of readState when power state changes to on and postComplete. Should only create the missing ones ie readState == type
Yeah, it's a bit heavy-handed at the moment...I'll see if I can find a simple way of making it more fine-grained.

Added a `createSensors()` parameter to filter it down to just newly-created objects in the latest revision; I'd be open to suggestions for a more elegant solution but I think it should basically do what we want here.
only needed with newOnly is true
Done
move to early after line 370
Done
lgtm

This feels like a work-around for a failure in the current design in that it misses an explicit representation of a device instance. It seems unfortunate that we have to go through the dance below to get correct behaviour.

I don't have a good picture in my head of the impact on the current code of fixing it. Any feelings on that front?

Essentially we'd need sensors to be aggregated in a device, and then to call destroy() on the device. From there run this loop moves internal to the device implementation to tear down its sensors and the logic becomes self-contained.

> This feels like a work-around for a failure in the current design in that it misses an explicit representation of a device instance.

Agreed.  However...

> It seems unfortunate that we have to go through the dance below to get correct behaviour.

I discovered after some experimentation that it actually behaves okay without the `deactivate()` step.  We do end up with the sensor still holding open FDs for the removed hwmon device, but it doesn't (I think...) actually try to do anything with them, so while perhaps inelegant, it doesn't lead to any observable misbehavior as far as I can tell.

> I don't have a good picture in my head of the impact on the current code of fixing it. Any feelings on that front?

Not sure offhand, but given the above my (lazy) inclination is to leave that particular worm-can sealed for the time being...

> > This feels like a work-around for a failure in the current design in that it misses an explicit representation of a device instance.
> 
> Agreed.  However...
> 
> > It seems unfortunate that we have to go through the dance below to get correct behaviour.
> 
> I discovered after some experimentation that it actually behaves okay without the `deactivate()` step.

.... How....?

>   We do end up with the sensor still holding open FDs for the removed hwmon device, but it doesn't (I think...) actually try to do anything with them, so while perhaps inelegant, it doesn't lead to any observable misbehavior as far as I can tell.

As a design pattern,this makes me cringe,but I guess it works?

> 
> > I don't have a good picture in my head of the impact on the current code of fixing it. Any feelings on that front?
> 
> Not sure offhand, but given the above my (lazy) inclination is to leave that particular worm-can sealed for the time being...


Isn't this as written going to mess with other sensors on any kind of change to any sensor?  One key learning we had early on was that we couldnt' just rebuild the whole sensor subsystem on every sensor config change.  Users didn't like it, and it resulted in slow APIs, and weird errors.  (ie changing a threshold on one sensor might cause another sensor to forget its power state.)

> > I discovered after some experimentation that it actually behaves okay without the `deactivate()` step.
> .... How....?

Well, the file descriptors stay open, but as long as nothing touches them...no harm, no foul?

> > We do end up with the sensor still holding open FDs for the removed hwmon device, but it doesn't (I think...) actually try to do anything with them, so while perhaps inelegant, it doesn't lead to any observable misbehavior as far as I can tell.
> As a design pattern,this makes me cringe,but I guess it works?

Agreed -- it isn't exactly pretty...

> Isn't this as written going to mess with other sensors on any kind of change to any sensor?

I don't think so -- note the `newOnly` parameter added in patchset 13 at Zhikui's request (unless I'm misunderstanding what you mean here and you're referring to some other problem).
...and with the above change the holding-stale-FDs-open problem also conveniently goes away.
.............   Can you give this a little more description of "why"?
Ack
Done

Looking at the only use of this, can we just return "newSensors".

Also, I don't think there's any reason it needs to be a flat_set, right?  Could we just return std::vector<std::string>?

There's a `newSensors.contains()` check inside the loop over the discovered sysfs paths in createSensors(), so an O(1) membership check keeps that from going unnecessarily quadratic.  But yeah, I suppose it might as well return it directly instead of via an out param.
Done
Do we need to check this?  Can we do the python thing of look before you leap, and handle the error where the device already exists?

Well, for one thing doing it that way would result in a lot of kernel log spam of things like

```
i2c i2c-5: Failed to register i2c client w83773g at 0x4c (-16)
```

which I think it'd definitely be preferable to avoid (in addition to just being noise, it's confusing and likely to lead people down wild goose chases of trying to figure out what's wrong only to eventually discover that it's hwmontempsensor "misbehaving as designed").

The problem there is that we run into the issue Andrew mentioned earlier (https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/dbus-sensors/+/56023/comment/e594059e_fb86f351/), i.e. that the sensor class represents a single sensor, whereas one i2c device may be shared by multiple sensors, and we don't have any representation of that in the existing class/data model.  Do you think we should restructure things to address that shortcoming before going further with this?  (I haven't looked into how much work that would be likely to take.)

I'm pretty sure this code has a similar problem.  A couple design patterns I can think of that would solve it.

1. Construct the i2cDevice object at a higher scope, then pass it into each sensor by shared_ptr (because the sensor instances share ownership).  When the last sensor is destroyed, the object will be destroyed, and the device removed.

2. what you suggested, abstract the classes such that we're constructing ONE class per device, and each class has one or more sensors.  This is my preference, but would require https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/dbus-sensors/+/37313 as a pre-req, which seems nuts to require for this kind of change.

3. Keep a singleton object for "constructed devices" that tracks the kernel devices and handles reference counting, and lookup for finding if said sensor is already contstructed.



FWIW, now that I understand the problem, this patchset as written is probably fine.  I'd still like to see one of the above patterns, but we can increment there over time.

> 1. Construct the i2cDevice object at a higher scope, then pass it into each sensor by shared_ptr

I had been sorta thinking about doing this, but ran aground for reasons I don't quite recall at this point.  However, after rearranging the device-management code to split out the representation of the i2c parameters as distinct from the instantiated device itself (and using an `of_node` check to distinguish static vs. dynamic devices) it ended up being fairly tractable, so that's now implemented in the current patchset (with two new infrastructure prep patches shoehorned in before it).
Can we put this after sensorPollMs? Or is there some reason it has to be constructed (destructed) in this order?

My thinking was that we'd need it to be ordered so that it gets destructed after `inputDev` to avoid the kinds of problems we had with https://github.com/openbmc/dbus-sensors/issues/20#issuecomment-1193004331 (i.e. to ensure that the I2CDevice continues to exist until after all I/O operations have stopped).
What driver doesn't recover if host power is restored? Isn't it a driver bug if it doesn't?

> What driver doesn't recover if host power is restored?

Hmmm...after experimenting it looks like in the cases I'm currently dealing with (w83773g and nct6775) it does in fact come back to life when I power the host back on (which in retrospect I suppose isn't surprising, for those two drivers anyway).

> Isn't it a driver bug if it doesn't?

This I don't think I'd agree with in the general case -- for a very simple device/driver it might often work, but if there's some non-trivial initialization of the device the driver does (e.g. writing a value into some register to set some particular operating mode) and that state gets reset on a power cut/restore I'd expect things could quite easily go pretty haywire.

Maybe? Shouldn't the operation to write the register fail, and whatever higher-level operation that caused the write try to deal with it again at some later point?

But regardless, that take is probably too deep into speculation and idealism. What you have can't not work.

> Shouldn't the operation to write the register fail, and whatever higher-level operation that caused the write try to deal with it again at some later point?

I meant if it does some mode-setting (or whatever) register write during initialization, that write succeeds, and then the device later loses power -- the driver doesn't have any good way of knowing that the write it did previously has been silently un-done.  I think it's essentially just a matter of luck that the two devices I'm working with at the moment don't really *do* anything to the device to initialize it (or at least nothing critical -- the w83773g driver sets a 2Hz conversion rate, but if that gets whacked back to its 16Hz hardware default I don't think the driver really cares).
feels like something that could maybe exploit std::bind_back (https://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/utility/functional/bind_back)?
Ah, neat, didn't know that existed, and yes, it does look like that'd work here -- unfortunately it also appears to require C++23, while we're still on C++20.
Updated to fix a bug wherein it would fail to instantiate devices when already in the correct power state at daemon startup.
Couple nitpicky things;  All are really up to you if you want to fix them or not.
Ah, didn't realize shared_ptr would default to nullptr...done.

One thing in the project we've been doing is to try to avoid these wildcard reference captures, as they can lead to problems.  I fully realize that you were just following what was done for io.post, and that's fine, but can we explicitly call out all the captures here, ie

[&io, &objectServer, &systemBus]
Done

I'm a little surprised that clang-tidy let you pass this by copy.  Normally we would do


const std::shared_ptr<I2cDevice> i2cDevice

i2cDevice(i2cDevice).


what you have works, and shared_ptr is about the cheapest copy you can make, so up to you if you want to fix it.
clang-tidy suggested the std::move(), which I didn't have initially...looks like you probably meant to include a '&' there though?  (At least, that's what clang-tidy then pointed me to.)
Yes, I meant to include a &

Oh, and https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/entity-manager/+/56128 should probably also get merged in the same SRCREV bump as this to avoid having hwmontempsensor and E-M fighting over who's in charge.
Ping Ed?

Just to be sure I'm reading this right, you're removing the sensor from D-Bus when the power is off?  That's different than the current power state checking, which just sets the sensors to NaN.  Why did you choose to go this way?

Yes, as it is now sensors whose power state isn't matched get removed entirely.  I had initially set out to merely deactivate them but leave them in place because I thought that having them disappear would cause problems for phosphor-pid-control (see discussion on https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/dbus-sensors/+/56022), but (a) I later discovered that removing them didn't actually cause the swampd problems I had been thinking it would, and (b) it aligned nicely with the object-lifetime-based device-management approach Ed suggested.

Are there other (non-swampd) current consumers of the dbus interface that would be broken by this approach?

There's also the slight edge case of its behavior when the service starts while the host is powered off.  With this approach it's consistent (the dbus object's presence is purely a function of whether or not the host is powered on), but in the "leave present but disabled" model we end up with an inconsistency in that the dbus objects are absent until the host is first powered on and then remain present from that point forward across arbitrary power state changes, leaving "host hasn't powered on yet" as sort of a weird special-case state (and one that it seems would also break any clients that would be broken by this approach when the host shuts down).

I guess I don't have any real strongly-held opinions on which way to go here, so I'd be curious to hear any other thoughts on this.  (Ed, Andrew?)

This behavior has other problems.

It doesn't match with the intent of either IPMI or Redfish.  Resources (sensors in this case) that are unavailable are supposed to be using the purpose-built unavailable statuses.  in terms of swampd, yeah, I could see it not being a problem, but the main driver for this behavior is users, and principal of least surprise.

I would expect the dbus paths to continue to exist all the time.  The only time I would expect the sensors to be completely deleted is in a hot plug scenario, which we admittedly don't handle very well.
Okay, so in that case I guess I should look into having the dbus objects get instantiated unconditionally as well (in addition to not deleting them), to address the host-hasn't-booted-yet problem...

...alright, having now started taking a stab at implementing that, I've realized a tricky problem:  before a given sensor is actually instantiated, we don't really know its type/units, and hence can't easily determine what dbus path to create the object at (e.g. should it be /xyz/openbmc_project/sensors/temperature/foo or /xyz/openbmc_project/sensors/pressure/foo?).

I can see a number of possible paths to take here, but none of them are terribly appealing.  Thinking out loud in no particular order:

  1. We could use some placeholder "unknown" type/unit until it's determined conclusively.  The dbus object would need to get deleted/recreated though (don't know offhand if dbus has a "rename" type of operation); not sure if/how much that would defeat the purpose.  PDI would presumably need updating, possibly some clients might need changes to accommodate it as well?
  
  2. In this particular case (hwmontempsensor) we could just assume it's a temperature sensor and delete/recreate later if that turns out to be wrong.  Downsides are that it might initially be wrong (and of course doesn't totally eliminate the delete/recreate problem).  It's also fairly specific to hwmontempsensor; if/when we try to extend this model to other dbus-sensors daemons there might not be an obvious default type.
  
  3. We could try to infer the type from the sensor's name (e.g. substring match on things like "press", "temp", "hum"...).  Kind of nauseating, but from what I can see in E-M it could work for all existing configs I think.
  
  4. We could rip out the IIO/non-temperature support and move it to some other dbus-sensors daemon, leaving hwmontempsensor handling only temperature sensors.  Is there another daemon that could reasonably accommodate it though?  Would it become a new daemon unto itself?  Also has the same "only solves the problem for hwmontempsensor" problem as #2 above.
  
  5. We could delay instantiating the dbus object until the first time the underlying sensor device is instantiated.  It'd be an unfortunate inconsistency, and would create a significant gap in the intent of aligning with IPMI/Redfish requirements.
  
  6. We could add explicit type/unit metadata to the E-M config schema.  Maybe the "cleanest" option, but also more invasive, and unnecessary in the common case (though perhaps it could be optional).
  
So I dunno...any thoughts on which of those would be the most palatable?  Or other possibilities I missed?
I suspect it'd be OK to not create the sensor until the system powers on for the first time.  I imagine that's how the CPUSensor daemons work too.
Yeah, now that you mention it I'm pretty sure that's true...so while perhaps not ideal, I guess it'd at least be no worse than the status quo -- I'll proceed with that then I suppose.

Alright, latest patchset implements that approach -- sensors aren't there initially, but do get populated when the host is powered on, and remain present (but unavailable/NaN) when the host shuts down.
This behavior make sense to me.
Yeah, I think you got it.  First power up can be weird.  We crossed that bridge a long time ago, and it's somewhat expected in most architectures.  Subsequent reboots should be consistent though.
This is not needed because line 473-476
Ah -- true, thanks.
same
Done
